text: you
I just returned from two weeks in Tehran
one of the most intense journalistic
experiences I've had and one of the most
extraordinary and radical changes of
mood in a place that ever seen in a
short time I think this election offered
the opportunity to bridge the gap
between the regime and a very young
society two-thirds of whom are under 35
who thirsts for more contact with the
world and that Mousavi represented a
possible means of compromise a man with
impeccable revolutionary credentials
who'd been close to Ayatollah Khomeini
who'd been Prime Minister through the
80s during the war period but instead of
using the election as a way to bridge
this divide I think the opposite has
happened there's been a power perch by
the most hardline wing within the
government and this has alienated many
more members of society so the division
between them where it was going let's
say at a 45-degree angle is now going in
diametrically opposite directions and I
think that will be a severe problem for
Iran going forward one positive result
at least in my view of all this is that
people in the United States had a rather
one dimensional view of Iran it was seen
uniquely through the prism of its
nuclear program people you said Iran and
people thought of mad mullahs and nukes
and nuclear Armageddon and I think
Americans today and this is a good thing
have a much broader and more accurate
picture of Iran as a society that proved
its vitality that proved its engagement
I don't think anyone will forget the
images of these people young and old
shopkeepers and students all kinds of
people putting their lives on the line
because they believe this election was
fraudulent and they wanted their votes
to count so instead of just seeing this
repressed
regime which proved far more brutal i
have to say then then I'd predicted they
now see Iran in a more rounded way and
that perhaps offers some opportunities
going forward for dealing with it more
effectively the clerical establishment
in corn has been very quiet it has not
endorsed the result Ali Akbar Hashemi
Rafsanjani the eminence grise of the
regime since the revolution two-time
former president is violently opposed to
what has happened and is working I
understand behind the scenes Mousavi is
clearly under some kind of near house
arrest but is still putting out
statements on his website he's not been
seen in public for several days and one
of the problems in the last few days i
was there was that he was not visible
enough to give direction to the millions
of people who are unhappy about what
happened one man to watch very closely
who I think will be a barometer of this
is Ali Larijani the Speaker of the
majlis or Parliament who has been
striking a rather measured balanced tone
he has said look we have to hear the
opposition they may have a case that
this was fraudulent we may have to put
mr. Mousavi on TV to make his case this
is pretty extraordinary coming from a
man who's close to Hammond a the supreme
leader but who hates Ahmadinejad and
it's not impossible in my view that in
the coming weeks or months there may be
a calculation within the Iranian
establishment that Ahmadinejad is simply
too much of a polarizing figure too much
of a symbol of this unhappy event to be
to remain in his position and he may
have to be thrown overboard
